pages.text: Just like the ordinary potions brewed by those not skilled on the art, potions brewed by a witch can be altered to manipulate the characteristics of the effects contained within them. $(br2)Furthermore, the magics involved in the process allow witches to further manipulate the effects, through the use of multiple pieces of the same       reagent.

Indeed, whereas a regular potion can only accept, for instance, a single piece of redstone to increase the duration of the effect, a potion brewed on a cauldron can take $(o)$(thing)up to five times the amount$(), generally speaking, thus allowing for longer potions. $(br2)As a piece of advice, however, do keep in mind that the usage of modifiers will also increase the magic needed to brew the potion...

pages.title: Redstone
pages.text: Just as it happens with regular potions, redstone can be used to extend the effect's duration...

pages.title: Glowstone dust
pages.text: Glowstone dust, as expected, can be used to increase the effect of the potion effect...

pages.title: Sagebrush
pages.text: The characteristics of this particular plant increases the radius wherein the effect manifests, but only on splash and lingering potions...

pages.title: Hellebore
pages.text: This delicate flower, on the other hand, extends the duration of lingering clouds...

pages.title: Brick
pages.text: The fired clay found in this item $(o)obviously$() makes the resulting potion effect ignore entities, thus not affecting them...

pages.title: Nether brick
pages.text: Antagonically, the remnant nether energies this brick holds makes it do the opposite, ignoring block effects instead...

pages.title: Particle supression
pages.text: Throwing a beetroot will cause the resulting potion not to apply particle effects. $(br2)$(o)Sneaky...

pages.title: Potion dyeing
pages.text: Lastly, throwing $(o)$(item)any sort of dye$() whilst brewing a potion will make the final potion be coloured as the combination of all thrown dyes.
